Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: Psychology 110 was easily the most interesting class I took during my fall semester.  It helped me gain insight about how the mind works and how everything we do has a purpose and science behind it.
A developed a comprehensive understanding of introductory psychology material.
This class definitely broaden my understanding of psychology and really made me understand the workings of the brain and mind better.
I obtained a factual, surface knowledge of many different areas of psychology. .
I gained knowledge about the history of psychology and the societal impacts of psychology on our world today.
Understanding of basic psychology and behavior
I learned a lot of psychology! I definitely have a new way of thinking about the brain and human behavior.
I learned ton about psychologyand and its respective fields
Basic understanding of psychology
I was able to learn how to read and analyze popular press articles about psychology experiments and how to do well in a big lecture course.
I learned that I am interested in psychology and that learning about it stimulates me
This course gave a very basic overview of the foundations of psychology. It helped introduce me to areas that I might be interested in for further study.

I got a broad overview of the basics of Psychology. I also gained insight into the process of conducting Psychological studies through the requirement to be a research participant in 5 hours of studies. I feel like my studying skills also improved as I had to memorize a lot of material for each exam.
Pretty much what I expected - ground level knowledge of the different areas of psychology.
I do not believe that I developed any skills in this class. However, I did learn a lot of really cool facts that are fun to talk about at dinner with my friends.
This course was extremely engaging and I gained a great deal of knowledge about the different subsections of psychology, much of which I found myself applying and seeing in my daily life.
I developed a broader understanding of human nature, which I think is valuable knowledge to have for any field I end up going into.

I obtained a lot of knowledge about how the human mind works. A lot of the things that I and others do every day are now explained. I can explain somewhat of what's happening in my mind throughout the day which is a really cool skill to have. It also made me realize just how much we don't know and also how to conduct an experiment and participate in experiments correctly.

This class was great in terms of material and knowledge - I have always loved psychology, and it is among the most interesting course material I've experienced. We learned a great deal about neurology and psychological concepts in general
A lot of common sense that was put under psychology vocab. Learned a lot of interesting studies and phenomenon. This was my first psych class ever, and I loved the lectures.

I learned a brand new set of skills on the brain and the mind apart from the usual scientific biology taught in high school. I became very intrigued in the different areas of psychology and the ways the it is taught/learned/used.
Learned the fundamental ideas of psychology; learned to succeed in a lecture-style class by taking notes not necessarily on the slide (by listening to the professor)

It reinforced my ability to memorize a lot of information for tests. I gained a breadth of knowledge about psychology and helps me better understand other people of all ages. I know this knowledge will help me in any field I choose to go into--having a better understanding of people, emotions, motivations, mental illnesses will no doubt aid me in interpersonal relationships.
You get a broad overview of all different psychology topics, from personality to sleep.
I gained so much from taking this course. I learned all the foundations of psychology in a very easy and engaging way.
Basic vocabulary.
Solid intro-level course
I learned the basic principles of psychology and some corresponding vocabulary. I learned about some very famous trials, tests, and experiments that have been done in the field as well.
I learned the overall introduction of psychology that I will use as a foundation for future psychology courses.
Learned lots of psych vocal and about different psych studies.
Covered basic introductory psychology topics.
I learned a lot about the workings of the brain and the experiments done to find out that information. I learned both about the physical aspects and also the mental aspects of the mind.
A good general overview of methods and content in psychology.

This course is a survey course covering many different topics throughout the entire field of psychology. The course touches on all aspects of psychology and really goes into depth on some topics that are not only relevant to psychology, but are also relevant to our daily lives. Errors of calculation, conformity, and how we develop into adults, there are many parts of this course that are relevant to our existence that I found interesting to study.

I learned enough to cover AP Psychology material but way more in depth knowledge of actual research. This course gives you a great overview of psych in a chill, easy to follow manner. You really need to learn to keep up with the material though because it can be an overwhelming amount if you put it off. This course teaches you to not underestimate a course that may be seen as a "gut"--this was certainly not a gut class.
I learned that the human condition can be studied via scientific inquiry.
Learned some useful insights into the human brain and why we behave the way we do

This class broadly covered a lot of topics in psychology that I had heard about in my life colloquially but put these musings into an academic setting. A lot of the class dealt with countering common misconceptions about psychological concepts and really helped pique my interest in the subject. I learned that the human mind is so vast and complex and truly deserves to be a field of study in its own right.
Learned how to better criticize works of literature about the brain and psychological occurrences.

This class was a great introduction to the wide fields of psychology. As someone who had no previous psych experience, I loved being exposed to knowledge of burgeoning fields such as neuroscience and the study of mental illness.
Gained a clear overview of the foundations of psychology.
I learned the basics of psychology across a wide variety of subfields. I became versed in the history of the subject, popular ideas in the 20th and 21st centuries, and the terminology of psychology.
This course provided a satisfying survey of intro psychology. Especially interesting/useful were the assignments that involved examining and critiquing scientific journal articles.
Attendance in lecture is crucial, for this class especially
I learned to study on my own and go through the textbook. This class also taught me the importance of memorization.
Learned lots of cool anecdotes about psychology as well as how to study for a multiple choice, memorization-heavy test.

This course goes over the basics of psychology. It is a broad survey of several of the field's focuses, such as development, perception, and psychopathology. If you haven't taken a psych class before, like me, you'll learn some interesting explanations for the way we think and see the world.

As a student who has never taken Psychology before, this course gave me a basic, wholistic understanding of the field, and provided a solid base for me to build my knowledge upon. I am not interested in being a Psychology major  I took the course hoping to gain a better understanding of how my own mind, and the minds of those around me, work. This desire was absolutely satisfied. In every lecture, I learned something (sometimes many things) that I could apply to my life, and left feeling as if I had reasons for phenomenons that I had always observed but could never pinpoint the cause of before. The course made me think more carefully about my interactions with others, and to always consider other people's motivations and thought processes.

I knew nothing about psychology before taking this course, but I learned and actually retained so much of the taught material. It was extremely interesting to me because I was able to apply these to my social interactions and to understand how the people around me and I think, and why certain strange things happen.

This class offered a strong overview of psychological principles, accessible to someone like me who is studying an unrelated field. Guest lectures from Yale faculty doing research in this field also helped provide insight into the kind of work that is popular in psychology today.

I learned quite a breadth of knowledge about the field of psychology, and I discovered I have quite the passion for it. I found myself fascinated with the mind (and its tricks!)  after this course, constantly researching recent psychological studies. I may choose to major in psychology after this course and PSYC 179 this semester.
I learned basic psychology skills.
I learned new things about different fields in psychology and facts about people that are relevant to daily life.

I just learned so much contentDr. Dunham has amazingly deep knowledge of every subfield of psychology that he presented, given that this was a survey course. He also had a phenomenal lecture style that made processing all this material easy.
I gained a better understanding of Psychology and its many applications.
Critically reading a textbook, looking at big pictures
I developed insight into the human mind.

I learned the importance of active listening and engagement. I love the fact that the course was structured in such a way that a student needed to attend lectures in order to understand the bulk of the information presented in class. This method of teaching also forced me to take detailed notes and ask questions of my TF when necessary.

I learned about many different aspects of psychology, mostly experimental over clinical, including social, developmental, and other psychology areas. I learned a breadth of information about the human experience and the scientific breakdown of human behavior, from how we grow and develop to how we interact in communities and groups to psychological disorders.
I learned an overview of the foundations of psychology.
I learned so much about such a variety of topics related to psychology. Even after the end of the course, I still find myself using the knowledge I acquired to think about everyday life around me.
We learned about all the basic themes and areas of psychology.
How the mind works
It was a great overview of psychology.

The course gave me a good understanding of a wide range of concepts in psychology. I developed my knowledge and gained insights into many interesting topics, from controversies in the field such as the replication crisis, to serious topics such as mental illness. The popular press article gave me skills important to navigating popular accounts of science in journalism.
I developed a solid, introductory understanding of basic psychology.
I developed a much more extensive knowledge and understanding of psychological processes. The class was really great at applying this knowledge to real life.
Learned a great deal about humans.
I gained a lot of knowledge about different psychological terms, aspects and studies.
I got to learn all the fundamentals of introductory Psychology.

This course gives students a very in depth understanding of the foundations of psychology. Our professor taught us about the different subject areas that make up the study of psychology, and different key subject such as materialism. We also covered psychopathology, which is the information used to diagnose people with mental disorders. I really enjoyed learning both the scientific and philosophical aspects within the foundations of psychology, as well as the purely psychological topics.
I learned about introductory psychology, and some interdisciplinary knowledge about behavioral economics and philosophy.
I gained a broad overview of psychology as a discipline and some of its main subfields.
I learned a broad overview of different types of psychology and also learned how to review a popular press article and become better versed in how psychological studies are written and reviewed.
I learned a lot about how the mind works and how psychology is seen in our daily lives.

This class is very set to the lecture slides.  The exams were sometimes difficult because they were very specific to the exact definitions explained in lecture and were always looking for some specific word.  Even when you showed full knowledge of a topic on an exam, you would still get point marked off due to missing a specific word that Dunham said in his lecture.

Strengths: Interesting material

Weaknesses: many students in lecture and no section, so there are limited opportunities to ask questions. However, you can always go up to the professor after class or email a TA/professor to get a question clarified. The questions on the exam also sometimes don't accurately represent what we learned in class/in readings.

This course is mainly based on memorization and the content can be very interesting. However, there are many aspects of the course that is lacking. The professor provides very limited preparation for exams, not giving us any practice exams, except a few questions that didn't illustrate the difficulty of the exams. There was no comprehensive syllabus describing what we needed to know for the exam and everything was very vague, so it was more of a guessing game when it came to what we needed to know.

I feel that the lectures of this course were very helpful and were very important to attend in order to understand the topics being taught but I feel like the test focused very much on very specific topics that were covered very quickly in class and that did not have very much emphasize placed on.

I don't think this class has very many strengths, and there were a number of weaknesses. First, the material was presented at a surface level and was not difficult; the material felt like it was at a high school level. Second, as a result of having such easy material, the sheer amount of material was rather overwhelming. Thus the class turned simply into an exercise in memorization. For anyone who's not a psychology major, you'll forget everything you learned in the class within weeks. Third, on anything that wasn't multiple choice, the grading with incredibly unfair and very nit-picky. If something was correct but not one of the options on the answer key, it was marked wrong. Clear expectations for assignments were not provided ahead of time, and assignments were graded so slowly that it was often difficult to apply feedback from one assignment to the next -- if it was given at all. Fourth, Professor Dunham likes to say he grades by a curve to help differentiate students and small mistakes don't mean a lot. However, his tests are, relatively speaking, rather easy, so there is not much differentiation. For example, on the second midterm, an 85% was a B+ and an 81% was a B-. Very similar performance on the midterm netted very different grades. Fifth, the curve is very difficult. For example, a 93% on the second midterm was a A-, not an A, and about 25% of people will end up with a final grade of C or D.

The strengths of this course include interesting topics paired with real-world applications. The weaknesses include long lectures that are often hard to engage with. Also, the final exam is cumulative and is given just a week after the last lecture that is included on the test.

The teaching staff did an excellent job creating midterms and finals that cover the information we learned thorughout the course. The powerpoints prepared by the teaching staff were excellent since they contained both the lessons from the textbook as well as additional examples of expirements. I did not like the ambiguous grading rubric of the weekly reading responses. One week, a certain response could earn you a 2/3 while in another week, a very similar response could earn you a 3/3.
The course is super interesting and isn't a super high workload.

Yarrow was great and the lectures were really fun and engaging. I wish I had received grades in a more prompt manner and had a better idea of what my overall grade in the class was. The tests were fair and readings were interesting.

Fantastic lectures. Would maybe like to have a section for the course so there could be more TF involvement. Wish there was more exam prep like a study session. Also would like the exams to focus more on reading material.
The 10 page paper felt a bit pointless to me, and lectures were definitely not as interesting as an intro psych lecture could be.

Even though it was a lecture, Professor Dunham did a good job engaging students with his lectures and I always did enjoy attending class. However, there are a good amount of reading responses (and a 2000 word popular press assignment) which I did not expect, especially since this course wasn't a writing credit. Another weakness was that grades took a long time to get back. Understandably, it's a large class but many people went into the final having not received the majority of their reading response grades.

Strengths: great material, engaging lectures, and challenging yet fair tests
Weaknesses: one page responses were not helpful, the TA's did not seem to grade the same for every response
I think that there should be more of a focus on how we can apply what we learn to our everyday lives

Strengths: very typical weekly routine - no surprises, balanced coverage of a variety of topics, engaging professor, standard structure for all exams
Weaknesses: unclear/inconsistent grading of reading responses, slow grading/feedback (though most likely due to a large number of students for very few TAs)

The material was extremely interesting, but the course itself is poorly structured with little to no avenues for help. Yes, you could schedule a meeting with a TF, but I would appreciate a discussion section to better understand the material.

I think the course is very standard. However, I did not particularly like the structure--reading chapters from the textbook and then listening to summaries of the same material in lecture. This process was redundant and boring. I would have preferred a range of material and more stimulating lectures that provided new knowledge. I also did not like the structure of the exams; they were either too easy or unreasonable.

The best part of Intro Psych was definitely the lectures. Professor Dunham was very engaging throughout, with well-organized PowerPoints that included diagrams and fun videos to illustrate the concepts we were learning. There wasn't ever a topic I found boring, and I credit that to the lectures.

I think there was a weakness in the required reading responses. They required that students choose 2-3 topics from the reading to respond to every week, which sounds pretty simple, except that it is difficult to respond to a textbook with information consistently presented as facts. I wish we had gotten more specific prompts to respond to each week (maybe a pool of them that we could choose one of to write). This would also have given more practice for how to write answers on the exams.

Grades on assignments, particularly the paper we had to write, came back very slowly, and we were not allowed to have our midterms back. This made preparing for exams and understanding our standing in the class particularly difficult.

I think this course is a very manageable, broad introductory class. It does a great job exposing students to many different fields of psychology, and keeping them entertained. I'm not sure how it could be improved, other than potentially finding a way to make students solve problems rather than regurgitate information.

Strengths: Extremely engaging material and lectures

Weaknesses: None noticeable

The course is taught efficiently and is well organizedclasses often ended early. However, the course is largely just rote memorization. Exams could benefit more from analysis or application of information to novel scenarios.

I thought the class was extremely interesting in that the subject matter was really intriguing and the lectures held my attention well. The reading can be a lot, but most of it is interesting, especially the reading that's assigned outside of the textbook. The reading responses could be frustrating because it seemed like the grading was really specific, and it was sometimes hard to tell what you were doing wrong. The level of intensity also seemed to vary widely across the TA's.

For the most part, the course material is interesting and offers a broad picture of psychological topics.

I found that the grades on weekly reading responses and on the mid-year writing assignment were given a bit randomly.

The class itself was pretty great - course material was interesting, although because we covered so much, we were not able to do any in depth analysis of one topic. But nonetheless, it was an enjoyable, well taught class - reading responses did what they were meant to: ensure that you at least tried to keep up with reading and class material.

Lectures were great - I loved Prof Dunham.

LOTS OF BS WORK. Weekly reading reflection were very pointless and waste of time. Also if you are unlucky, your TA will use them as a way to dock points. The midterm essay was also WAY longer than it should have been. Most people end up BSing and it takes the TAs forever to read through them. Too much unnecessary work.
Faster grading.
Lectures were good. I didnt really enjoy doing all the reading responses and felt that doing 6 was unnecessary, considering that I wasnt interested in every single weeks topics.

I really liked the lectures and I think having us do reading responses helped me actually complete the readings on time/in full. I would have liked more one-on-one attention, especially around the tests. Perhaps having some review sessions?

Strengths: course was laid out well, with reading responses due every week that reinforced concepts in lecture; Professor Dunham's lectures were all very interesting and he gave the right amount of examples and definitions to balance out
Weakness: It's difficult to keep every student engaged (nature of lecture style class); grading wasn't always consistent and left many students wondering how they're doing in the class

The course was nice to take, but I thought the reading responses were a really arbitrary assignment to give. I understand that it was suppossed to encourage us to read and delve further into a topic of our interest, but I don't think they're a more accurate assesment of whether or not we did our work then multiple choice questionsor something of a similar nature. In addition, the grading system seemed very random. I wasn't sure what  gave a response a 2 and what warranted a 3. The one page on the syllabus telling us what was expected from a reading response was not very helpful either.

Not sure if this can actually be improved on, but, as a freshman from a small community, it's difficult competing with most of the class--most of whom are sophomore premeds who will all be aiming for an A. Even though I feel as if I know the information quite well, I will most likely be getting an A-, an admirable grade but despite the amount of studying I put in/knowledge that I feel I know and took away, it doesn't quite feel right to me.

I think a weakness of the department is that Intro CogSci cannot substitute as the Intro Psych prerequisite for the major/higher level courses when the courses felt very similar. I definitely think I would have gotten more out of Intro Psych had I not already taken Intro CogSci. 
I also think that Intro CogSci is a generally better designed course, largely because of the readings. I found the Intro Psych textbook to be relatively unhelpful and that it tried too hard to be funny. Reading responses also felt superfluous since I wasn't trying to digest particularly difficult material. Sometimes I looked up primary sources on my own based on the textbook reading, but I generally think it would have been more beneficial and more interesting to be reading particular articles as case studies of the concepts we were learning than to be reading textbook chapters--something that Intro CogSci does very well. 
The Intro Psych lectures however were very well organized and Professor Dunham was an excellent lecturer.

Strengths: 

Good, organized lectures!


Weaknesses:

Terrible grading. As in, I had no idea why I was getting the grades I was and also the grades would come in like months after I finished an assignment. My TA was super distant and cold and would barely respond to e-mails asking if I could see midterm scores, or why I got grades that I did.

The lectures are good but I was so frustrated by how arbitrary all the grades felt. Practice what you preach when it comes to good learning; I got barely any feedback all semester. I feel like people who are experts in psychology should know better about how to handle these classes. Yes, it's a large lecture, but having been in too many giant intro STEM classes, the grading could have been handled better.
Needs discussion section.

Dunham is a good lecturer, but curve is so rough (average to B-/B) that you basically get whatever your raw score is in the class. Also, turnaround for assignemnts is incredibly slow despite it being the TA's only job (no section). Still haven't received a small reading assignment grade from November 10th (it's December 22nd).

The course covered a lot of information well and the activities run in the class kept students involved during class. It was really hard to study for the exams though because it was difficult to tell what was important for them.

The grading of reading responses out of 3 points felt very arbitrary and really harmed the grade if 1 or 2 points out of 3 were given, since there were so few reading responses and not much room to recover. I think dropping the lowest grade is a better system rather than not doing 1 of the responses. I also think grading out of more points would be a better system as well.

The lectures were interesting, but the text was terrible. It oversimplified all of the material, to the point of making cute little jokes to explain concepts in the dumbest way possible. This made reading responses particularly difficult to do, because you were supposed to engage with the text and talk about some interesting aspect of it, whens most of it was not very interesting at all. I preferred the supplementary papers that were posted as readings for some of the lectures - these papers actually went into depth and treated their topic with more attention and thoroughness.

Strengths were the teaching and lectures.  They were really cool and supplemented with cool videos that keep things interesting despite the long class.  Guest lectures were also cool!  Weaknesses include the grading on the exams.  It was super unclear what was expected and points were taken off for dumb things like not explicitly saying one word despite otherwise fully answering the questions.  They also took FOREVER to grade things.  So you had no idea where you stand in the class.  Starting off credit/D it was hard to make a decision given we had gotten pretty much nothing back.

Strengths: Lectures were extremely interesting and relevant to day-to-day life. Really changes the way you think about your brain and how the world works. 

Weaknesses: Curve is really unforgiving. Also, the long written assignment can be quite annoying and unnecessarily long. You also get very little feedback about how to improve on writing assignments.

I think the class is structured well. We learn a lot of material and the tests are not hard. However because the tests are not hard the curve is very bad. I don't think this class should be curved because if everybody has achieved an A level understanding of the material then they should be rewarded accordingly.

The course is well taught, and lectures are very clear and engaging. The most obvious weaknesses are the sometimes strangely written test questions and the very, very slow grading speed, which makes it difficult to improve based on any sort of feedback.

The strength of this course is that the content itself is interesting. Prof. Dunham is, although maybe a little calm and dry, entertaining and usually has a good story to tell with every lecture. Lectures were actually fun to go to and they were always filled with interesting information. The course is excellent in giving a great survey of the field of psychology, and it even made me consider majoring in psychology.

The weakness of the course is that, in terms of grading, assignments are not graded fast and many times you don't have any idea what your grade is. Reading responses have a certain format that need to be followed, but if you don't uncover that format, then you'll be getting middling scores for all of your responses. Maybe it was my TA in particular, but comments left on responses were very vague, and it was hard to improve when they were graded at such a slow pace. Even if the comments were life-changing, they came a month after I turned the assignment in, and I would have already turned in three responses, and they would be subject to being graded as if I knew what to fix.

The strengths are definitely Prof Dunham. He really knows his material and I'm impressed by his ability to lecture without hesitation. He truly comes prepared and he also has a good sense of humor. I really liked the pictures/videos he showed of his daughter. In terms of the midterms and final exam, I think it was really fair the way the test is written. I really appreciate that Dunham posts a few sample questions for us because the actual test is pretty close to the format. 


Weaknesses are hands down the grading system of this class. I think there are clear discrepancies in the way TAs grade. I also just feel that this class is set up in a way that it is easy to do poorly. For example, you have reading responses, but because they are only out of 3 points, if you lose even one point, that will harm your weighted average of these reading responses. You really don't have a large margin for error in these, and it becomes a bit hard to think of creative ideas for these reading responses because I felt that once I found a way that earned me a 3, I was too afraid to venture to say new things in each of my responses. I also really disliked the research component we were required to do. I wish it could be a part of our grade because I think this was a lot of work, and would have been nice to have gotten credit for it. (For those who don't know, you're required to do 5 hours of research participation for this class, and it does not help your grade; it can only hurt your grade by a full letter grade if you do NOT complete all 5 hours).

Professor Dunham is an outstandingly clear and engaging lecturer. The material itself is fascinating and fun. The readings, though, felt like a waste of time since, although they were a pleasure to do, they never appeared on any exam.

Strengths: the midterms and final were very good representations of what we had learned over the year

Weakness: readings,lectures

This class is very subjective and unfair. There is not a lot of continuity in grading across TF's. Also, I did not particularly like the experiment requirement in the class. It seemed like a waste of time and I did not really learn nor engage with the experiments that I did participate in. Moreover, this class is essentially just a memorization class. The majority of your grade is exams, which are essentially just a test of what you can memorize. Lastly, the popular press article was harsh in that it was an unconventional paper yet little help was given on how to do well on it.

The course was extremely straightforward yet very interesting, which was a major strength. The lectures were extremely engaging. However, I felt like we covered so many topics that it was hard to get more than a cursory look into many interesting topics. Of course, that may just be the nature of an introductory class but perhaps having time to really commit things to long-term memory instead of just to working memory might be interesting to consider.

Strengths: interesting topics are covered
Weaknesses: we are not taught how to design experiments which we are asked to do in the exam.
Extremely relavent to daily life.

The course provides a strong foundation for the field of psychology; the implications of this is that some lectures are more interesting than others, and sometimes the lectures may not go as in depth as desired. One important note is that computers were not allowed in class for the purpose of taking notes, only pencil and paper.

This course does a good job presenting the raw material, like facts, historical information, and the views of eminent figures. The information is comprehensive, and the class appeared to not cover any more information than was necessary. This was also somewhat of a weakness for the course, since the rote absorption and memorization of information could become exhausting towards the end of the term.

Lectures were very engaging and readings outside of class (especially the journal articles) were helpful and enjoyable. Textbook readings were less useful and more redundant of in-class material. Tests generally felt very reasonable, while grading of written assignments felt much more arbitrary.
This course was extremely interesting for me, as someone who had no previous knowledge of Psychology. I genuinely found the lectures fascinating and looked forward to class.

This class seemed typical of an intro course, but it often seemed like the tests contained information that had been very briefly mentioned in lecture and were never touched on again. It was also incredibly frustrating because the TFs were absurdly slow to grade assignments, so reading responses would not be graded for weeks after they were due. The same occurred with the tests. Also, I received no feedback on the majority of my assignments.

TAs were brutal. They all graded differently, slowly, and often harshly. I think it is so hard to do well in this class that it took away some of the enjoyment. The material and instructor are so fascinating and I wish I could have embraced that more freely.

The lectures were engaging and often involved videos or stories about real people that exhibited the prevalence of the things we learned. They were also very organized and easy to take notes on and understand. The course was straightforward and interesting. However, the grading was a bit confusing at times. For me personally, my TF had a busy schedule and was slow on grading, so I didn't get frequent feedback on reading responses, and I wasn't quite sure what the expectations were for the popular press writing assignment.

Strengths:
- this course provides a very wholistic overview, making for a very good introductory course in which students can get a taste of many aspects of the Psychological field.

- Yarrow Dunham was a wonderful lecturer, and made each lecture engaging, thought provoking, often funny, and always worthwhile.

Weaknesses: 

- The teaching fellow grading my reading responses and papers never gave me more than one (very short, vague, and entirely unhelpful) comment. Thus, I did not know how to improve my work, and felt that maybe they weren't putting any actual thought into reading and grading my assignments. 

- some of the outside readings (particularly the article on heuristics) were very difficult to follow, and didn't seem necessary to the course 

Ways to improve: 

- ensure that teaching fellows are required to give substantial feedback 
- cut out any reading material that is unnecessary to the course

The strengths of this course are that the professor was extremely good, and that the material tested was identical to the material taught (no completely abstract thinking). The only weakness, in my opinion, was that the assignments were graded extremely slowly. I understand that it is a large class, but that is why there are TFs. Some assignments took months to reach Canvas, and I just found that to be a bit too much.

Professor Dunham's lectures were thorough and understandable, and the course overall was very well-structured. All in all the class was pretty  low-workload (two midterms and a final aside), but it is on a curve and it's far from an easy A. I did find that the weekly reading responses didn't help me all that much -- I think that something like writing weekly summaries of recent psychology papers might be more effective, and give students a broader overview of the field and what kind of research is popular today.

I believe this course is very strong in terms of content and engagement. I think the lectures were fantastic--Professor Dunham is amazing. However, I believe the curve is graded partially unfairly. Since every student has a different TF, their reading responses are graded differently. This means that, if one TF grades more easily, those students get an advantage on the curve. Additionally, some TFs give a lot more feedback on reading responses, and this compounds the disparity. I believe if this course took a note from ECON 115, where every single students' pset was graded by a single TF, then the next pset was graded completely by another, this would make it more fair and it would leave the same amount of work on the TFs' shoulders. This was my biggest issue with the class, as those few points from reading responses can bump you up a bracket on the curve--something that should not be left up to alphabetical chance.

There are very few strengths to this course. The material was generally good for an introductory course but this was not reflected by the material on exams, where an obscure detail in a lecture slide would be tested on. The feedback in this course was absolutely abysmal. There is no chance for a student to see how their work could be improved upon before completing new assignments (mainly reading responses). Grades were released after excessively long periods of time. There was absolutely discrepancy amongst TAs in grading standards. The short answer and essay portions of exams were graded unfairly in my opinion, with subjectivity of the grader a big portion of this problem. I think this class has great material and is important but many of the ways in which it is run can hurt students depending on your TA.

The strengths were the lectures, which were engaging and well organized. The weaknesses were the long time it took to get feedback on assignments and the ambiguous grading on the popular press article and the reading responses.
I think the lectures were really well done, and the workload was very manageable.
The class was taught at a fast pace but I received a strong basic understanding of a broad spectrum of psychology.

I would either start incorporating more information from the textbook into the exams or be more clear about which parts of the textbook will be relevant to the tests. As it is, there were only two or three questions per exam that relied on understanding the text (not just the lectures), so I didnt want to waste too much time studying the entire huge textbook when I knew I probably wouldnt remember whichever two or three random details in it were tested anyway.
This class was great except for the required participation in studies. I understand why they do it, but it was inconvenient and unrealted to anything we studied in class.
This course was very interesting.

The strongest aspect of the course is that it forces students to stay engaged with the material that is presented in class. The lectures, reading responses and essay encouraged students to check their level of understanding constantly and consistently. The weakest aspect of the course is the sheer level of material that is presented. It was difficult sorting through the chapters in the textbook to recognize which information was most relevant to the course. On several occasions there was material from the textbook that was noted as unnecessary only after the fact.
Great professor, but slow to grade reading responses and receive feedback from the TFs.

The lectures were great and very intriguing. The weekly readings were a fair amount of work and were enjoyable assignments. I would say the class should have more than 4 TAs, as giving each TA 30+ students cuts back on the feedback they can provide to each student individually and makes it take much longer for students to get feedback. For example, I would get scores on my reading responses so far after I turned them in that I never really took the opportunity to use my past results to modify my responses going forward, as it was just too late.
The lectures are interesting but with the difference with what we learn in class and in the textbooks its hard to know exactly how much you should know.
A strength is that the lectures were engaging. A weakness is that we were slow to receive grades/feedback.
The strengths are the engaging lecture style and the availability of the TF. Getting grades back more quickly is probably the biggest place for improvement.
This course is very slow.  I did not enjoy it.  Only take this course if it is required.
I felt it was a good course overall without much, if anything, in the way of weaknesses.

The course material is very interesting. A weakness of the course is the TA system; without having any actual sections, I didn't know my TA at all and found it difficult to communicate with them. Optional sections should definitely be available. Also, students shouldnt have to participate in studies to get credit - I don't think I really learned anything from the studies. Students should, of course, be encouraged to participate in the studies of their own volition.

Also, the questions chosen to test us in the midterm and final were annoyingly designed to test rote learning of minute details or exact definitions in the textbook. A better, deeper and more interesting way of testing knowledge would be to have questions testing a more conceptual understanding of the material rather than memory of the exact words of a definition (i.e. fewer multiple choice!).

It was really interesting, and the lectures were very helpful. I didn't find the textbook to be very helpful in terms of success on tests and other assignments. Mostly, all of the information came from lectures and what he had said, and this made it hard for me to make sure I knew all of the information for tests.

One strength is the variety of topics covered during this course. In addition, it was taught very well through the main professor, in addition to several guest lectures. The information was organized well and correlated well to the textbook material. One weakness might be the lack of discussion section to summarize material, but this is mainly due to the self-taught nature of the textbook material.
It was just hard to take this along with other hard classes. Thought would be easier.
There was little opportunity for feedback as assignments were graded way after the semester was over.
The course is full of an abundance of information. However the grading is a bit slow.
Strength is that every aspect of modern psychology is covered. Quality of lectures is excellent. Weakness is that feedback can be slow sometimes.
I think the course did a good job of giving a broad overview of psychology and the different areas of study. It covered a lot of material.
I think that this course would benefit from a section, in order for students to discuss the readings and formulate reading responses. Other than that it was a very interesting and informative course.
This class is not hands-on at all. I think a discussion section could facilitate this, but at the same time I think a discussion section would not be holistically beneficial.

Overall I really liked this course! I thought that lectures were vere very engaging and enjoyed the opportunity to delve further into the the material through assignments. I felt that the popular press assignment was especially effective at giving choice to examine psychological research of particular interest. I also really liked the opportunity to hear from guest lecturers who are active in the field. 

In terms of weaknesses, I wish there had been more ways to interact with the material and teaching staff. I think an optional discussion section could have been a nice addition in order to increase engagement. I also feel as if the exams emphasized rote memorization over conceptual understanding. Therefore, I think it would have been helpful to have replaced an exam with an additional paper and/or to have made the exams more conceptual in nature. Also, I felt like I didn't gain that much from participating in the psychological research studies. Perhaps each study could have counted for more credit time and included talking to the researchers about the study and writing a brief report which ties it into course concepts.
I think the information is presented in a logical manner but that sections should be added to the course structure in order to promote focused discussions.
The lectures were of a great quality of information; however, it would be nice if they were more interactive, as it is difficult to sit in a dark room for over an hour and just write down notes.
I would most definitely recommend this class to another Yale student.  This class was extremely interesting and definitely opened my mind up to maybe even studying Psychology here at Yale.
I definitely would. It is interesting information, and I think some of the concepts are important for everyone to know.
I would not recommend to take this course in the fall, but I have heard that the spring semester course is better.
Yes, I would definitely recommend this class to others because I feel like it was very interesting and it was definitely a class I enjoyed going to.

I would absolutely not recommend taking this course for a number of reasons. First, the material was presented at a surface level and was not difficult; the material felt like it was at a high school level. Second, as a result of having such easy material, the sheer amount of material was rather overwhelming. Thus the class turned simply into an exercise in memorization. For anyone who's not a psychology major, you'll forget everything you learned in the class within weeks -- you'll get nothing out of it. Third, on anything that wasn't multiple choice, the grading with incredibly unfair and very nit-picky. If something was correct but not one of the options on the answer key, it was marked wrong. Clear expectations for assignments were not provided ahead of time, and assignments were graded so slowly that it was often difficult to apply feedback from one assignment to the next -- if it was given at all. Fourth, Professor Dunham likes to say he grades by a curve to help differentiate students and small mistakes don't mean a lot. However, his tests are, relatively speaking, rather easy, so there is not much differentiation. For example, on the second midterm, an 85% was a B+ and an 81% was a B-. Very similar performance on the midterm netted very different grades. Fifth, the curve is very difficult. For example, a 93% on the second midterm was a A-, not an A, and about 25% of people will end up with a final grade of C or D. I would strong recommend avoiding this class.

I would recommend this course to students who are genuinely interested in a major that requires this credit. The amount of work you put into this course is not always directly correlated to your grade. TAs are never punctual when returning work and are always busy with other commitments.
Yes. This course is an excellent introductory course for both those who have a passion for psychology and those who are just curious to dabble in this social science.
Yes! Interesting class and not a huge workload
Definitely. I think this class was very fun and interesting and was not exceedingly difficult.
Amazing lecture series, but grading can be a little difficult even if you read the book. A great course to cred/d/f or audit. 2 midterms, final, and an essay.
Yes, the content was extremely interesting. The professor was engaging and had a great teaching style as well.

Eh. I mean it's not an awful class by any means, but there are some lectures at Yale where you leave saying "WOW!" every time, and it's just not that way with this professor (Dunham). If it's with Chun or something, definitely take it because then it will be one of those classes. 

That said, if you think you may be interested in the psych major or need to take psych for any reason, it's a pretty good class, you learn interesting information (even if Dunham doesn't always deliver it in a super interesting way), and it's definitely changed the way I look at human nature.
Yes but be aware it's not going to be easy and is a lot of work

Take it if you want to take more psychology courses that need this as a prereq, but if you can use AP scores to skip out of Intro to Psych, there's many other great psych courses that will probably be more enjoyable since you'd be able to focus more on a topic within psychology that you're more interested in.
Yes, I would recommend this course to a student looking to gain a wide basis of understanding in psychology.
Yes because I found it fascinating and also not overwhelming. it isn't hard to get a good grade while learning a lot

I would recommend this course. A lot of the topics covered are really interesting (but they will only be covered very briefly). Professor Dunham does a good job of making the less interesting topics more engaging, and he often injects a sense of humor into his presentations. This course makes sense as a prerequisite to the psych major, as it covers breadth rather than depth. The workload is very reasonable, and the exam structure is consistent and straightforward though often heavy on memorization. My one critique would be that reading response grading is often slow, and it can be difficult to do well on them.
Get out of it if you can--the curve is too harsh, and the teacher is poor.

I would not recommend this course with this exact professor. If there is a different, more engaging professor, then I would recommend the course as it does offer a good overview of the basics of Psychology.

I only took this class because I am premed. It is pretty necessary in order to take the MCAT unless you self-teach the material. The class is pretty interesting but I suspect I will quickly forget most things that I memorized while taking this class. Not a bad social science credit.
Absolutely. Whether you think this is a subject you want to pursue further or not, this course is exceptionally taught and exceptionally interesting and applicable to your daily life.

Psychology is a great course to take, no matter what you want to study. It will help you gain insight into how you think and what can motivate the behavior of others. The class is pretty dry, but worth it if you need an easy SO. Because the class is largely just memorization, though, it tends to become tedious if you aren't totally enthusiastic about the material.

I would recommend this course because the subject matter is something you can apply to your everyday life. It gives you an appreciation for the human mind and all of its good and bad quirks. It's a good way to decide if a major in psychology is correct for a certain person.
An interesting survey of topics in psychology -- would recommend!
Yeah, it's a great class
Content was interesting but work was unreasonable. Maybe consider Intro Cogsci but I don't know anything about that course.

Yes, I think this course was fun and well taught and I enjoyed attending class because the lectures were stimulating and interesting. I think anyone from any major would also find it interesting to explore.

I would recommend Intro to Psychology to another student, whether he/she is interested in psychology or not. The course contained really interesting information about how the brain works and I think it was an intellectually stimulating and enjoyable class to take.

I would recommend skipping if you can--I don't feel the class was worth the struggle to try and get a higher grade
Most people taking higher level Psych courses that I have talked to have said that Intro Psych was the hardest, and that most of the knowledge learned in the class was either retaught or not needed.

This is a solid introductory course. If you're interested in taking a psych course in your time at Yale but don't need Psych 110 as a prereq or for a major, I would recommend taking Intro CogSci instead. I took both and found them to be of similar difficulty but found Intro CogSci to have more interesting readings and be slightly more thematically organized. That being said, if you do have to take Intro Psych, I enjoyed the course and Professor Dunham was a good instructor for it. The material was both clear and interesting, and I feel both that I learned something and that the course wasn't particularly taxing.
I honestly wouldn't. Sit in on some of the lectures, maybe, but I was frustrated by the end of all of it. So much rote memorization for such little pay-off.
I would definitely encourage other students to take this course. It has made me reconsider my major and I have found a new interest in psychology.
Only if the individual was interested and passionate about psychology
I would definitely recommend the course.

I'd recommend for the knowledge and as an intro course, but if you're hoping this will be an easy A after AP Psychology or something from high school, you're mistaken. Tests are fair but very detail oriented (like one slide from his lecture on one particular term) - so a lot of studying is needed.
Yes, it is one of my favorite classes that I have taken at Yale. The professor is great and the class is really interesting.
Yes, it was very interesting and I enjoyed it a lot!

It is a great introductory class and the lecture is really cool and had lots of videos of fun and interesting experiments.  I actually wanted to goto lectures.  The exams are not hard and straight memorization.  They are a bit harsh and nitpick on the grading though which is super annoying and probably ended up being inconsistent.  They also took FOREVER to give back grades.  you basically have no indication of how youre doing ever.

Yes, Dunham is a very good lecturer who will make sure you enjoy going to every class. Well-worth the hassles of the weekly reading responses and long writing assignment. The class is curved pretty harshly though, so your experience will depend heavily on how the TA grades your assignments.

Yes, it was a great overview of human psychology, quick paced enough to keep you interested but detailed enough to leave no gaps. Professor Dunham does a wonderful job in lecture as well, very engaging.
Yes I would recommend this course. It is a good course that let's you understand yourself and others better. There are some pretty interesting topics that we cover.

I would recommend this course, both because psychology is a generally interesting and important subject to have a basic grounding in and because the course is well taught. However, be prepared to get assignments back weeks or months after you turn them in.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. The course is relevant to our daily lives and teaches students things that are important to keep in mind. Discrimination, conformity, and violence can all be boiled down to fallacies of psychology, and it was eye-opening to think about how important it is that we all realize that our own prejudices are but mere consequences of misguided psychology. I think that everyone should take this course, if only to get that.

Yes! If you need to take this class, that's one thing, but if you just want to learn more about psychology or need a So credit, really consider this class. I will say I heard that the spring semester is usually taught better, but I think Dunham did a fabulous job.

PSCY 110 is a truly outstanding course. The material is engaging and the lectures are fun, clear, engaging, and insightful. Its grading system and workload are reasonable. I would recommend this course to any student looking for an enjoyable and intellectually fulfilling course.
if they are interested in psyc, sure. I was not, and found it difficult to engage

I believe this is a great introductory course because it is so straightforward yet interesting. The current set up of the class rewards the student that takes the time to attend class and read through the textbook in a way that is not the case in many other classes.
I would highly recommend this course -- Professor Dunham is a great lecturer and makes the content really captivating.
Yes! Super interesting and a fun class.
It is a tough intro level course because alot of topics are covered over a short span of time but it is interesting so yes, I would recommend it to another student.
Hell yes! Yarrow is the best, and the class is both simple and straightforward as well as informative.

I would recommend this course to another student who is interesting in gaining an overview of the field of psychology and may be interested in delving further into the field in the future. The workload for the course is really manageable, and it provides an introduction to the main topics of psychology.

I would recommend this course to another student. This course covers a wide variety of interesting concepts that are also relevant to everyday life. The class is well structured for learning, and the coursework is light enough that you can actually enjoy the material taught. The information is taught and presented in a way that makes it manageable for any student, even those with absolutely no experience with psychology before.
I would recommend this course.
Yes. It was very easy to follow the material and actually an enjoyable things, something I often forget about learning,

The content of this course, namely in the textbook, was quite interesting and I would recommend any student thinking about psychology to take the course for that reason. However, I would caution them about grading for the course, as grade distribution often seemed very strict, and discourage students who value feedback from taking the course.
I don't know that I would - unless they want to major in psychology. Taking the course a fun way to learn new things seemed to backfire on me.

If you're at all interested in psychology or haven't taken a class before this a good course to take. It will bring you through the basics of what you should know and introduce you to interesting articles and ideas. The course isn't an automatic A. Understanding the concepts isn't difficult, but there's a lot to remember and this presents the real challenge of the course. However, as someone without an academic psych background, I found the lectures and reading consistently engaging.

Yes, I would recommend this course to another student who is interested in the Psychological field, whether this interest is big (a major) or small (simply a desire to learn). Psych 110 is for everyone.
I would recommend this course to another student simply because it is so interesting. It is not that difficult and the tests are manageable as long as you show up to lecture.

This class is unrelated to my major, but I found the content to be accessible and incredibly interesting. Professor Dunham is a fantastic lecturer, and the class requires relatively little time commitment. The class is on a curve though, so it's definitely not an easy grade -- I would certainly recommend shopping and perhaps taking it Cr/D/Fail.

I would recommend this course to another student for the following reasons:

1. It provides the best overview of psychology and allows people to figure out if they have any further interests in psychology.
2. Professor Dunham is amazing!
3. I enjoyed the course.

I would not recommend it to a student if they already knew basic psychology or they knew they weren't interested, as the problems with grading makes taking this course almost "risky" to a student's GPA.

I would not recommend this course to other students. If you like not having an idea about where you stand in the class throughout the semester, then this is the course for you. TA discrepancy is at an all time high here.
I would recommend this course to other students interested in psychology as the course provides a good broad overview.
I would highly recommend this class.

I would recommend the course to any student regardless of major. Its really not too difficult and youll learn so much information thats relevant to both your own life and insights in whichever field youre majoring in (i.e. econ, political science, biology, really anything).
If they are interested in Psychology and have never taken a class on Paych before, then yes! Otherwise, no.
It was fine, not too heavy of a workload, but they're a bit picky with grading.
Yes, this was an interesting and beneficial course.

I would certainly recommend this course to another student. Being that the course was intro level, I expected to have a lot of information thrown at me without any consistency; this was not the case, however, because I was able to make connections between all of the chapter and the material was presented in a cohesive way. I also enjoyed going to class and I was always interested in what we learned in the lectures.
This course is a great way to delve into psychology and get a broad but in-depth overview of the field. The workload is very manageable and the lectures are entertaining.
Sure! You learn a lot of topics and the professor is nice.
I would definitely recommend this course to a student who is interested in psychology or sociology but still has room to figure out exactly what they are interested in.

Absolutely not. I did not like this course at all. The lectures were slow and nearly put me to sleep. Also, the lectures are only pictures, so if you miss any slides while taking notes you are screwed. I find this to be unfair.
Would recommend to anyone interested in the working of the mind
Yes, it's a very interesting topic.
Yes
Definitely
I would, but only if they want a survey of psychological topics. Apparently it isn't really needed as a prereq for further psych classes, and I wish I had known that.
Yes, if interested in psychology.

This course is a great introduction to psychology, and it is really well-taught. Even if you have previous experience in psychology from high school, you will still learn some pretty neat stuff in this course. The workload is reasonable, and grading is fair. If you are interested in the processes that make us human, this is the class for you!
Not unless they are trying to major in psychology.
No
Yes it is full of interesting information and easy to understand.
Yes, I would definitely recommend the course to another student who wishes to learn about introductory psychology.
I would recommend this course if the student wants a broad overview of psychology or just an introduction.

I absolutely reccoment this course to anyone who is interested in studying psychology who has not studied the subject in depth before. I would also recommend this course to students who are not interested in studying psychology specifically, but who have a scientific background/interest and might want to receive an extremely exciting overview of the foundations of psychology as a subject.

I would recommend this course to any student interested in psychology, both as a major and for fun. It's a very broad course, much like AP Psychology in high school, but in much more detail than the AP course.
Truly outstanding course. The perfect balance between detail and general concepts

I would recommend this course to another student. I think that the large lecture format/survey nature of the course mean that it won't necessarily be one of the most inspirational/mind-blowing courses at Yale. However, that being said, Professor Dunham is a really wonderful and engaging lecturer who helps to make the material come to life. Also, I feel as if I learned about some really fascinating studies in psychology and certainly hope to continue learning about the field.

I would highly recommend this class to another student. The lectures were engaging and interesting, the readings were fascinating, the projects were enjoyable, and sections were helpful to promote reading discussions.
I would recommend this course to another student, as it is applicable information in everyone's lives, no matter their major.
